description:
My favorite latte in the city. 

 Smooth and silky espresso with high caffeine content and little to no acidic kick back.   

  I always stop here when I'm in The Haight ! 

 There is a clean Bathroom for customers and that is awesome on Haight Street  
 
Customer service is always on point, and I have yet to receive a burnt milk latte.   
  
    My old favorite Blue Bottle sold out to Nestle , so no more if that for us.. 
 
Stanza all the way !
author: Niki J.

description:
Super super cute coffee shop off of Haight street - very well decorated and laid out with tables near the front windows and past the coffee equipment near the back of the shop. Pretty hipster interior. I paid $5 for a soy latte ~grande size, although there were no sizes, and it was great.

The pastries looked to die for. I wish I hadn't just eaten because I definitely wanted a few things! They had HUGE croissants, cookies, scones, etc. 

I have walked past this coffee shop so many times and never gone in so I'm glad to have finally gone in and tried the coffee. I'd recommend it!
author: Bri T.

description: Really good coffee, chill atmosphere and good people. I' glad that I stopped by! I grabbed a cup of black coffee so no earth chattering remarks or insights to share. If I'm in the area, I would definitely swing by again to try something else.
author: Daniel W.

description: This cafe is nice. I stopped here for the second time. I had an Americano or something. I don't know. It was a hot coffee and not just regular coffee. Kept me up all night. I talked to the owner and asked him about the coffee-making business. I wouldn't do that myself, would I? It's got a nice interior and people are quiet.
author: Denise C.

description:
This is a cool little coffee shop on Haight Street. The coffee drinks are done right -- made to order with great beans. I opted for their Americano. It was made perfectly. The staff were hip and playing cool tunes. There was a steady stream of people wondering in and out of Stanza. Many of them seemed to order something just so they could take a quick break and, to be honest, use the bathroom. Jokes on them because the bathroom was effing gross!

Either way, as a coffee shop, Stanza is great. I'd love to try their 12-hour drip coffee next time.
author: Will S.

description:
Great Dirty Chia! Perfect temp and they didnt burn my almond milk, which most places do. 
I go here typical once a week and it never disappoints
author: Taylure R.

description: They have delicious tea and a nice cool place to sit down. The staff is hip and nice and helpful. I enjoyed a chai tea and my friend enjoyed a hibiscus mint iced tea. It's quaint but comfortable.
author: Opal B.

description: I look for politeness and cleanness, here , you will get that! I came across this cozy coffee shop to ask if I can charge my phone. They welcomed me in without me paying for something.
author: Diego A.

description:
Stopped in for an afternoon pick me up. Nice place, very clean and friendly people. Loved that I didn't have to go through the whole Starbucks like ordering here. 

They made the perfect mocha and a timely manner. Would go back for another cup!
author: Brigid D.

description: The latte milk was PERFECTION! Bernadette was awesome and I am grateful for my fabulous evening coffee!!! I will be returning thanks to her!
author: Christopher D.

description:
I am bummed that I forgot the name of the gal that was working but it was around 6:30pm this past Friday on 1/19/18. She was super sweet and she really knew how to make a chai with my extra favorite honey add in! I melted and what a place to just have a moment to sip something great! Read a book, bring a lap top, relax and people watch as they walk by the windows. It really was a nice and quaint little joint on Haight st! 

I'm telling you, the chai with honey, YUM!
author: Stephanie M.

description:
I was surprised to see reviews re: racism
I was served by a Japanese gentleman who helped explain Kyoto coffee to me, I love that they have vegan goodies (even if it isn't readily apparent).

The Kyoto coffee:
I usually don't leave pretentious reviews but I actually tasted notes of caramel and fruit (acidity). Really wonderfully and smooth. Would def recommend 
Deductions: Minus stars for bathroom (dirtiest I've ever been in, I didn't want to touch the handles or sit down even after putting down paper towels) and no wifi 

PS: I liked the music (upbeat coffee house stuff)
author: Yusuf K.

description: Adorable coffee shop in the Haight with a peaceful vibe. The latte is delicious and you can tell the barista takes her time to make each drink. A little pricey but worth it.
author: Sejal D.

description: The barista who worked Saturday afternoon was rude to my friend who was unfamiliar with the different kind of coffee drinks. The barista wouldn't even speak to him, she just stared as he asked what and americano was. It made him really uncomfortable and I felt awful for taking him there in the first place. The drink he got was watered down and made poorly. I don't care where you work, being rude and apathetic in any job reflects poorly on the company.
author: Emily M.

description: C'mon we asked for our coffees for here but they said they are closing soon (it's 7p and they close at 8p) so they refused to serve us in cups for here.   Is it too much to ask for a real cup to enjoy your coffee?!?
author: Carlos Q.

description: Really great coffee. Awesome chill staff and a very welcoming mellow cafe atmosphere great for hanging out.  Best coffee on Upper Haight!
author: Goth Kitty Jen J.

description:
We've been regulars for probably 3 years, and even though two new coffee shops opened a few blocks closer to home we keep coming. 

Stanza brews Counter Culture and has the best pour-over, as well as the best (and best-priced) batch brew coffee in the area, hands down. These kids know their coffee and make it right.

(The owner is surly and kinda rude, but he owns a bunch of shops around and is fortunately rarely here.)
author: K D.

description: This cafe is excellent.  One of the few cafes in The City I have been to where there is both a good environment and that is not excessively bourgeois.  Tricky to pull this off.  One of my favorites in SF for sure.
author: Antonio A.

description:
Usually perfect. 

Occasional loud music problem, but not enough to complain about. 

Here, in this little coffeehouse on Haight, I have often had the friendliest service I've had since living in the city.
author: Tim W.

description: The cocoa was delicious but it was done a bit bland. It was still sweet, but not sweet enough if that makes sense. It was smooth, though, so that was nice.
author: Jose V.

description: Americano was strong with a nice well rounded flavor.  Hot chocolate was great, creamy and not too sweet.
author: Issy M.

description: Awesome, awesome cold brew, simple and intimate, but modern interior and decor, friendly staff, and a cool place to post up and work. Definitely recommend stopping by while you explore H-A
author: Tanmay A.

description:
This place really has stepped it up since it first opened. The coffee is still great and the design is even better. It's very spacious and has a lot of counter top space you can use to work on your laptops. Their wifi is pretty fast as well. They have SO MUCH POTENTIAL.

But BEWARE if you want to come here to sit, chat, work, or study. My main problem with this place is their choice of music. It honestly sounds like nails on a chalkboard/screeching cats/nail splitting pain with zero words and zero melody, AND this music is disturbingly loud. 

In addition, the bathrooms are really disgusting. They really do look like Haight St. -- they smell, are dirty and are horribly lit with aggressive graffiti all over it. Overall, if you're coming to hang out for a while, go somewhere else down the block.
author: Michelle N.

description: I ordered a Kyoto-style cold brew here, the coffee tastes pretty good and the lady who served me was kind. The atmosphere in the cafe is pretty chill and relaxing, definitely a good place to go in hippie district of SF.
author: Tiffany T.

description: This hidden gem is at good as it gets. One of the better coffee places in SF! I highly recommend. Staff was pleasant, loved the ambiance, art and overall decor. Very cool vibe and the drinks were great too! I can't complain :)
author: Tania G.

description: Like many businesses on Haight St, Stanza Coffee Bar has a customers-only bathroom policy. My friend had to use he restroom so we went in and payed $7 for two cookies. My friend went toward the restroom and the cashier says under her breath, loud enough for us to hear "just as i suspected..." really? Why the attitude when we just payed for these overpriced, stale, bland cookies!
author: Clara S.

description:
Really awesome community and coffee here.  I really enjoy the espresso shots, but have been trying and like the bar drinks.

They make the fancy shapes with the cream in the top of the coffee, the little things.

For the price it's a good deal on Haight, and I enjoy somewhere close by I can start my day.

Thanks to all the awesome employees
author: Michael K.

description: The lattes here are served only with one size, and it's pretty small. Kinda too foamy but otherwise good.
author: Albert N.

description:
So they don't have wine here anymore apparently. Seems like they'd change their name but oh well.

They also didn't have non-fat milk, which my friend was disappointed about. 

Otherwise, the coffee was good. Latte art was solid. Cute place to hang on the Haight.
author: Kelly G.

description: This was possibly the worst experience I've ever had in a coffee shop.  The worker there who was a young woman with short hair was EXTREMELY rude.  To a point where it made me uncomfortable being in there and I wasn't even in there for more than 10 minutes.  She had the worst attitude and the coffee was not good. Bottom line I will never be returning to this shop.
author: Bailey S.

description: Nice coffee shop in haight.. nice staff and nice decoration, excellent capachino.recommend everyone to visit there to have the coffees
author: Surendra K.

description:
Yikes. 

I came in here with a couple friends to escape some hot weather, and was essentially forced to flee the premises after getting yelled at by the tall, surly, blonde-haired man behind the counter. 

THE PROBLEM: I asked for a double espresso poured over ice.

I did not know that this was akin to Ned Stark's crimes against the Seven Kingdoms, and that I too deserved to lose my head. 

After paying ($2.50 + $0.50 tip), and using their heinously disgusting bathroom (you have been warned), I arrived at the counter, just in time to watch the single cube of ice melt into what I could only assume was 1 shot of espresso in the worlds tiniest to-go espresso cup. 

I assumed this was an error in my ability to communicate what I wanted, so I got Mr Surly Blonde Man's attention, and very nicely, asked for a slightly larger cup of ice (so that the beverage would be cold, instead of its perfectly awful 70 degree temperature).

He then attacked, cut me off and demanded to know what I would be using a bigger cup for (to ice the beverage, and to leave room for cream), accused me of wanting to add milk (yes, I want to add milk: Coffee+ Milk: Is this a new concept?), and then took me through a laundry list of reasons why he cannot accommodate me, a paying, tipping customer. His biggest issue was the addition of milk to the equation. Milk, to hear him tell it, is a commodity equivalent in price to Rhino Horn.

At that point I just asked for a refund, which he gave me, along with the report that "Usually people don't want to ask for a bigger cup because its awkward. So you're lucky that I have the time to talk to you." 

I told him that I felt like the luckiest girl in the world. 

--

TLDR: Don't waste your time. This place (or at least this tall angry blonde dude) doesn't know how to treat humans, and they don't have a monopoly on espresso drinks.

People go to coffee places as much for the ambiance and the customer service as for the coffee. I hope they figure this out soon, as well as change their milk provider; it sounds like they're getting ripped off.
author: Nicole F.

description:
Great little coffee bar and great people.
The coffee lived up to my expectation and I was impressed at how much care went into making everything for their customers
author: Amanda T.

description: Cozzy place after a long walk around Golden Gate Park. Tried the apple empanada and made me feel like in home.
author: Riki C.

description: Just got an Americano and an almond milk mocha. Both are mediocre at best. The woman who served me was barely present, which I wouldn't have minded if she had made good drinks. I won't be returning
author: Scott L.

description: This was one of those places that you choose because it has 4 stars here. Two words, watered down. 3 drinks: regular coffee, mocha, and a cocoa. 3 chances, and all 3 were failures. My coffee was so   weak it could barely hold it's liquid form. My son's hot cocoa (because they don't carry juices) was like chocolate water. Ew! And he didn't even get to at least enjoy whipped cream on top, because they don't have that either. Plus, I didn't know Dixie cups started making coffee cups. That was the large size?! Well, it was a $12 lesson that hopefully saves someone else from making the same mistake. The artwork inside  was very cool, P.S., by the way. So if you are in the market for some intricate coffee stained artwork, then by all means; check this place out. For a good cup of coffee; look elsewhere and let me know...
author: Monica F.

description: The coffee was pretty good and is probably the best shop for the Height-Ashbury area. It is also the only on that is open late so that was a good perk. I really enjoyed all the art that was for sale on the wall!
author: Daniel C.

description: Coffee was aiight but the almond croissant was just bad. The filling had a very weird and overly salty flavor. I gave it away to a homeless dude, which I feel guilty about because it was that bad. Waste of $8
author: Sunshine K.

description: Solid third wave coffee. As always based on some form of Americano. This was unexpected in the neighbourhood since most of these places are closer to downtown.
author: Stuart A.

description:
Why I'm giving this place five stars. Simple answer get the Kyoto style iced cold brew. You'll Thank me later. 

Ciao
author: Linda N.

description:
Solid small coffee/espresso menu.
Good pastries.
There is a restroom & wifi.
Lovely artwork.
Window seating in front, bar
and a couple tall tables in the back.
3 stars for ambiance.
author: Anisa A.

description: Really awful service. Guy didn't want to serve us coffee in regular glass cups at 7:20 because they were closing at 8pm. Really? He had an attitude about everything.
author: Kat L.

description:
Damn good espresso drinks here!

What really got me to love this place is the fact that I could actually taste the espresso with my almond milk latte.  Some other well-known coffee shops (whose names will remain "sight"less) make almond milk lattes that taste so bitter because they burn the almond milk hearing it at ether too high of a temperature or for too long.  

Anyway, I really like how light and airy the lattes feel at Stanza.  It's also just a super cute place to go for a date or to hang out and possibly do work if you had to.

Would return again :)
author: Monica J.

description: I'm loving the latest table upgrade! The new tables are so much more sturdy, clean, and generally set up well for working and/or socializing.
author: Ariel M.

description: Haven't yet gone to another coffee place in this area but the latte was good, presented well, and a very friendly barista which is definitely a necessity I don't see often in coffee shops! Also it's nice that there is an area to sit and chat, and a bathroom
author: Karin U.

description:
This place is a welcome relief from the surprisingly mundane coffee spots in this area. The place is in a main drag of haight district. Plenty of things to do nearby and the setup is inviting for one to just take a break and unwind. I had the cappuccino here is the verdict
Espresso:mild to medium
Crema': Good
Milk: Frothed well
Latte Art: Good 
3.5 Stars for the cappuccino
author: Elvis A.

description: Coffee bar that has very cute decorations.  However, I saw a mouse crawling underneath my feet and their bathrooms and hallway to the bathroom is disgusting. Tons of huge spiders on the ceiling and the bathrooms look like they never get cleaned.
author: Regina A.

description: Visited here from Toronto and even though I'm not a big coffee drinker, I came with a friend who suggested it. He really enjoyed his pour-over and I had a mint tea which was perfectly fine. Only complaint is that there wasn't room at the front for us to sit at the tables so we sat at a table at the back but it was incredibly wobbly. To the point where we couldn't touch the table at all and when the barista put our drinks down on it, a whole bunch spilled over the rim. The barista topped up the coffee but the drinks continued to spill throughout the time that we sat there and eventually we just made a huge mess.
author: Bethany Y.

description:
I think this is the best coffee in the Haight. Friendly staff and usually there are tables or places at the bar for you to sit. So you can definitely come and chill. 

I had no idea they served wine, which, with a name like this, I assume that they do.
author: Mariko F.

description:
Small selection of pastries and great coffee options. My table was the top of a barrel, which was very cool.  There was also a big bar to sit at. I couldn't decide which to pick. 

For you health nuts, keep in mind there's only 2% milk.  I'll walk it off.
author: Bahman M.

description:
I have never been made to feel so uncomfortable to the extent of having to leave a negative Yelp review...

My friend & I came in around 5pm Monday, we both got a latte which was good but quite mediocre for the price ($4.25 for a small cup).

After ordering I had to use the bathroom and tried to open the door which was locked. As any person would, I assumed it was in use, sat down and waited for the door to open. 
I waited a few minutes and someone else walked towards the door which then buzzed, allowing the person to walk in.
Realizing it was a buzz-in door I asked the barista (a tall girl with dark, curly hair and glasses) to open it for me, to which she very sharply responded "there's literally a sign on the door telling you to ask the barista to open it."
Feeling super uncomfortable & almost embarrassed I said "oh ok...sorry?" and used the bathroom which REEKED of a disgusting, stale pee smell (i doubt these are cleaned on even a weekly basis).
I left the bathroom, still feeling put down by the rude a$$ barista only to have my friend tell me that in front of her that same barista was talking sh*t about how "clueless" I was to her coworker! 
RUDE and unprofessional.

Please, for the sake of your customers, get rid of these arrogant, clear-framed-glasses wearing angsty hipster baristas!
It's not that hard to be nice! :)
author: Emily N.

description:
Love the atmosphere of this place. The coffee here is really good but a bit pricey for the size. The small is literally midget. 

Good study area. Wish they were open later!!
author: Juliana P.

description:
Here's a great spot to chill in the Haight that is not a tattoo parlor or some random tshirt store. This Wi-Fi cafe has all the elements for people watching, laptop surfing, and good conversations. There is a large wine bar sitting in the middle separating the vertical interior into two seating areas. They have a hipsterish following and the foot traffic is persistent most of the day. 

I tried the Peanut Butter Chocolate Chip Cookie ($3) and it was soft, moist, and dark chocolaty. One of the baristas was cleaning around my area and apologetically offered the cookie as a show of appreciation. The cookie was rich and good to share.

The Coconut Donut ($3) was out of this world. Super moist, refined, cakey and organic. They get their donuts from Pepples. Since this visit my mouth waters every time I'm reminded of their cakey donuts. 

Soy Latte ($4.50). Unfortunately, the consistency of soy was too thin and not creamy enough. The espresso quality was muted and lacked complexity. It was okay but not the best others had claimed it to be. 

Service was direct, efficient, and amenities include Wi-Fi and plugs along the walls. 3.5 stars for the overall experience. It was a positive experience but there are also many great cafes to choose from in the City. I will only return the next time I'm the area.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I love stanza! 

That being said.... I moved from the mission to the Haight and can't imagine coming to this location and there being literally only one mediocre pour-over option here! 

I loved the 16the street location's turning point and multiple other options. Can we get this going on Haight street please!
author: Paloma S.

description:
This trendy hipster cafe is squished between the bohemian and vintage shops on bustling Haight Street. They serve up fine brewed coffee prepared by a mustachioed barista -- frankly, I'd expect nothing less. You'll see a mixture of hippies, tourists, and drifters all standing in line together to wait for this cup of joe.

Easy parking: Good luck finding a meter.
Large drink under $5: Yes
Friendly staff: Yes
Indoor seating: A few wobbly tables that if you barely bump your delicious caffeine will spill everywhere. Seriously, I did it and we saw two other people do it too at other tables.
Outdoor seating: None
Decor: Dark neutral colors with artwork from local artists hanging on the wall.
People with laptops: Yes
Hipsters: YYYEESSS
Famous Faces: No
Foam Art: Yes
People watching: Great!
In & out quick: Yes

The challenge continues!
author: Kevin R.

description:
A cute quaint place to just sit and relax with a good cup of coffee or tea. 

Their walnut scone was good. The person behind the cashier was really nice too :). Their tables are these cute barrels too.

Going to their restrooms is like a distance though haha.
author: Jerianne G.

description: i like the look i think the location is awesome but the girls this saturday afternoon taking my order and making my gibraltar were not the most ...upbeat. maybe like a pinch of hipster snobbery. some dude ordered water and while i fault him for not questioning why he was being charged for 2 cups of water the look that the girls gave him and the awkward sinking in of what just happened as 2 cups of coffee were presented made me feel a little bad for the guy. i mean the fact that he was willing to pay for tap water!! jeeze lolol give him a break. and from my personal experience the girls seem like they are just whatever not necessarily rude just wouldn't describe them as super friendly and smiley. some ppl don't give a crap about that. but i really didn't think it was appropriate of them to make more comments about the water situation after the guy had left. so... the gibraltar. it was ok i've had better elsewhere. won't come back since ritual coffee is nearby lolol. so much coffee in the bay for me the excellent customer service is that extra vital thing that keeps ppl coming back other than proximity i guess. i will take my discretionary income elsewhere.
author: Reese A.

description: Came in here with my friend and loved it! The atmosphere is great, it's pretty small, so it can get a little crowded. Their lattes were great, and the employees were really friendly and fast!
author: Kalina K.

description:
There's nothing hot or exceedingly cocoa-y about their hot cocoa. Tepid milk with a vague rumor of chocolate about it. 

The staff are pleasant and social, at least when I've visited.
author: Christopher M.

description:
Charming little coffee spot on Haight which was recommended by a local. She claimed Lemony Snicket was written here & that of course peaked my interest. It's a tiny shop with a dark cozy lounge area toward the front & diner style seating toward the back. Interesting mix. I loved their unique coffee drip system on display. So cool. Definitely got a hipster vibe. 

I went for the Guatemalan pour over, purely because I've never had it & liked the look of the glassware. So, it's basically a system that allows the barista to control the brewing process to preference. I felt excited watching them do it. Coffee was excellent. People were helpful enough. So, I'd go back. Maybe I'll run into Daniel Handler the next time.
author: Elena F.

description: I wanted to to like it. Just waited 9 minutes while the barista cleaned the bar and chatted with his friend. 8 people in the place. Honestly, I thought they were playing a joke on me. On to the next coffe eshop I guess. Place looked cool, I just needed the cup of coffee.
author: Alouicious J.

description:
Iced coffee 4 stars. Price for coffee + pastry with no refill or even refill discount price and no water readily available (have to specifically ask for a glass?), minus 1 star.

Great people-watching vantage point though.
author: Victoria C.

description: They don't serve wine here so sorry to disappoint you if you read the name. Apparently yelp won't let them change it. BUUUT have no fear. The coffee and service here is BOMB. I got a cappuccino and it was awesome. I personally would want to change the back area into a cool patio for customers since it was already getting full on a Tuesday afternoon. My friend knocked my drink and spilled a little and he gave us a brand new capp. You can just feel the love that the owner has in this shop, just like most independent businesses of SF. Also, smell the beans on the shelves. It's a vacation for your nose.
author: Angela C.

description:
Not wanting to be inconsiderate and hold up a table at Pork Store Cafe down the street, my friend and I migrated here after lunch so we could just sit and chat. Your typically quaint hipster cafe, with some limited seating both up front and in the back, and tables make out of upcycled wooden barrels.

I ended up ordering one of their pourovers, going with the Kilenso Mokonisa from Intelligentsia, which was surprisingly tastier than expected. Better than Philz? Nah, not really. But better than anything I've had from Blue Bottle, that's for sure - though, admittedly, I'm not a fan of the more sour, acidic coffees that many a person here seems to be, and that seems to be pretty much all Blue Bottle has these days.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Another fairly small space, but I'd say about half their seating is accessible, albeit possibly a bit cramped.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description: The coffee, the service, the atmosphere. All perfect. Was exactly what I was looking for on this glorious Saturday morning!!! Thank you
author: Kaitlyn V.

description: Good coffee, normally a good place to get some work done but this morning the baristas played loud bad music and danced behind the bar, joked loudly with one another. I know it's not a library, but this was just annoying. It went on for at least an hour before I gave up waiting for them to chill out and left.
author: Alicia G.

description: Was a great experience until the change of shift and the music was on blast.  Very straight menu.  No space for a small group of 4 just 2 at a barrel table.   Cute design but very dirty drug infested bathroom.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Worst espresso I've had in years. 
Barista felt he was too good for the job. 
Toilet seat covered with piss. 
Overall not a great first/last impression.
author: Peter O.

description:
My first visit here left me smiling even after I walked out the door... I also think it had to be my most enjoyable food experience during this past weekend visit to SF.  The barista was extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and down to earth.  Seducing chocolates, chocolate chip cookies, and as their name reflects, they offer wine, coffee and more.  I was mainly here for a little sweet after a savory breakfast.  

Iced Coffee:
I was so intrigued by the Kyoto Slow Drip Filter and the fact that takes 12 hours to filter Iced Coffee.  The barista took the time to explain the who, what, why, and how.  This filter's slow process allows for the coffee bean oils to seep through and the finished coffee product maintains the integrity of the coffee beans (this easily and quickly occurs with the hot water process).  It's a full bodied iced coffee that would be great on a hot day.  I had a sample and it was bold in flavor and body.  

Mexican Hot Chocolate:
The Mexican hot chocolate (enough cayenne and cinnamon to add more flavor to the palette) was so delicious and the spiciness kicked down the sweetness. The barista indicated that they will soon introduce a ganache cocoa made in-house.  She also mentioned, sad face, that the Mexican hot chocolate will likely be phased out as the current chocolate vendor discontinued this item, but Stanza may continue to make it with the newbie in-house ganache cocoa... hopefully they do when I come back to visit!
author: Nova P.

description:
I wasn't too impressed, but it was good coffee for a good price in a clean cafe.

The cool drip coffee thing they've got go into helping with the hip atmosphere they like to portray. It's right where everything is happening so it's a cool place overall
author: Robert R.

description:
Used to live a few blocks from here and I miss this place being my regular spot. Baristas are super nice, have solid taste in music, and make damn good cappuccinos. 
I like Stanza more than a lot of coffee shops in the city because it's good without the awful pretentious/hipster vibe.
author: Ryen W.

description:
This is my go-to coffee shop. Not only is every shot pulled to perfection but the staff is friendly and always has great stories.

WARNING: Sometimes the music can be loud and offensive.

Still... there are power outlets aplenty and FREE WIFI! Why is it hard to find that in this town these days? Well, this place has it all. Good job guys. Keep it up. A particular shout out to star coffee slingers Spencer and Robbie.
author: Andy D.

description:
'Artisan' coffee treats

If you love coffee and do not mind waiting a while in line and then for your order you won't be disappointed with the result the barista created for you.

The coffee deserves 5 stars, the atmosphere/seating not so much -furniture/chairs have seen better times...

Coffee: from $2.50
author: Travelin- M.

description: So far this is the best cuppa jo to go in the neighborhood. I'm also a fan of the ambience and the baristas are always v chill and pleasant!
author: Emily S.

description: Great coffee, nice staff, and better wi-fi strength than at Flywheel.
author: Alex T.

description:
Didn't have the coffee.  Had Moroccan mint tea and iced tea.  The scone was awful, tasted at least a week old, very stale.  I ordered the raspberry turnover because the guy recommended it over the apple turnover -- except, then he gave me an apple turnover.  It wasn't bad so I didn't ask for the error to be corrected.  But for $18 for 2 beverages and 2 pastries, I would have expected much better quality.

The cafe was not very clean -- half the tables and the counter were covered in crumbs from previous guests, not to mention sticky.  (I've worked in the hospitality industry so I'm very well aware that keeping a place clean for your guests means you'll make more money for both your employer and yourself.)  Music was horribly LOUD; it's not a club.

I guess it's the Haight, though, so maybe this is normal.  And why I don't hang out at places in the Haight.  Cole Valley is much better and only a few blocks away.  If you want clean tables, walk there.
author: K S.

description:
My first time here, ordered only double espresso but hella great double espresso is served at Stanza.

I will return when next in The Haight.
author: Jay D.

description: The first macchiato I've had that tastes exactly like the ones in Rome. The cute barista adds points too. :)
author: Jessica H.

description:
Turn down the music a bit.

High quality espresso coffee. The Counter Culture beans are good and the espresso is properly made. I can't fault anything here (although, if you are a fan of the more old fashioned, dark roast espresso, you might find fault). 

For me the only drawback is the music. The selection is pretty good, but it's just too loud for a cafe. It's above easy conversation volume and even a bit annoying when waiting for a shot.
author: Jice E.

description:
TL;DR This is my favorite coffee shop in SF. I've been to a lot, too.

I'm not really in a position to attest to the experience of this coffee shop if you're popping in for a quick drink and running out, but what would a yelp review matter in that context anyways? If you're there to have a chat with people who are passionate about what they do, but more importantly are enthusiastic to know who you are, what you're about, what brought you to the city, what music is playing, or where's a good spot to grab a bite to eat, it's perfect. The shop is clean, the drinks/food delicious, the bar has plenty of outlets for your devices, and the staff could care less if you spend a long time sitting there working and reading and jamming to some music.

If you're having a hard time finding a smile from an assuredly exasperated employee and you're on yelp to confirm you insecurities that a person who was too stressed and too busy making complicated and delicious drinks for the long line of impatient customers to give you a forced smile and the patience your (no more than) $5 buys you, you're doing it wrong.

If you want a place however where you can sit down, plug in your phone/laptop, get a little work done, hear some really awesome music, enjoy some unique art from local artists, talk coffee, talk music, make a few new acquaintances, drink truly delicious drinks and eat truly delicious pastries, and get an overall feel for the hardworking, positive, interesting, and energetic vibe that Haight street made a name for itself on, you've come to - not the right -, but the perfect place.

I work remotely out of coffee shops, and I have the entire time I've lived in SF. I've been to one in every neighborhood, and some are really great. Having said that, Stanza is my favorite coffee shop bar none. By such a wide margin, I'd feel embarrassed if they ever saw me anywhere else.
author: Kevin C.

description: So at 9 months pregnant I stopped in to use the restroom and they would not give me the key until I waited in a long line first to order something. Additonally, the coffee I ordered was absolutely terrible and the atmosphere is misguided hipster. I ended up tossing the coffee before I left.
author: Anastasia J.

description: Visited here from Los Angeles and it was really good coffee! I ordered a latte and it was wonderful...my only complaint is that the tables we sat at were wobbly so the wonderful latte art was ruined when it spilled :/ other than that, I would definitely recommend this place for those visiting Haight!
author: Jackie P.

description:
If you're looking for a place to stop and have a quick cuppa, Stanza would bit it. 

The half wine barrel tables are kitchy. The location is great, right next to Loved to Death, and the selection of drinks is pretty fabulous. EXCEPT.. the coffee has been over roasted, it tastes burnt.  

I was rather impressed with the latte art though. It was stunning.
author: Dianna B.

description:
Where Cole meets Haight :) not only is this place a must visit, it's a perfect place to sit at the window with coffee or wine & people watch. 

Ruu, la la.

My order was a "pourover" coffee with, get this, a Nutella pop tart. The barista heat it up & it was a perfect treat to end my afternoon. Can't wait to return & play the pour over vs. the French press test.
author: Priscilla N.

description: I like the relaxed atmosphere, kudos to the very calm woman working behind the counter. A good place to rest when you need a hot drink.
author: Trista B.

description: My fave on upper Haight for a coffee.  One of the two places in the city serving Counter Culture coffee.  Rare single-farmer beans sometimes available.   People here know what they're doing.  Great music in the background.   Wine Bar in the evening.  Gotta come by for that soon....
author: Kelly P.

description:
The coffee is pretty good and the big bar is cool, but they definitely don't have it dialed as well as some of the good coffee shops in the city. Yes, they are in the Haight so the standards are probably lower. 

Stanza is neither roasting their own beans nor providing much information on who does. They have a slow drip system (slow drip to old plastic bucket, that is) for iced coffee. Unfortunately my cup had so much ice packed in it I was afraid I wouldn't be able to get the lid on. In fact, there was such a small amount of coffee I chose to leave the lid off and sip it. 

Stanza runs a mediocre operating that really annoyed me. I won't be back, and I won't be recommending it.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Bravo Stanza!  I finally dropped in and ordered a cappuccino this afternoon, and I was very impressed.  I'm thrilled to finally have top-notch coffee on Haight Street!

The tables were a tad uncomfortable (thick enough to prevent leg-crossing, and the one I sat at was pretty wobbly).  That's my only complaint.  But that will prevent laptop jockeys from hogging tables for too long in this small cafe so that may be by design.
author: sean s.

description:
Ok Stanza, I've loved your espresso brews and been loyal for a long time.  Lately though, you're slipping just a bit.

The atmosphere is still great, but there's a constant revolving door of new baristas.  It seems like someone is always training and the new crew just hasn't perfected the craft.  Drinks are now scalding hot and inconsistent.

Don't get me wrong, Stanza on Haight is still one of the better coffee shops in the city, but that extra special touch of magic is gone.
author: Helene O.

description: Staff is awesome, love the espresso! This place is solid and full of city life if you can shimmy around the tourists.
author: Jane D.

description:
Very different look than their 16th street store. Coffee is just as good and the pastries are even better. Pretty loud and they have music playing in the background. Not a whole lot of room for seating indoors. But I didn't get the chance to see if they had a patio. The coffee bar is right in the middle of the room and creates a place to sit. 

Good wifi and friendly staff.
author: Laura D.

description: One of the best coffee places in the Haight. I like their slow bar and also their donuts (from Dynamo, only available on the weekends). Pretty good scones too. It's not a bad place to do work.
author: Ryan Y.

description: Very rude barista, OK coffee. They also have some pastry, nothing exceptional. They are way too arrogant for the quality of the products that they are serving.
author: Meric O.

description:
The place is okay. Went by one afternoon to meet someone I'd met at a networking meeting. The macchiato and cookie I got were both good though both overpriced in my opinion, especially the $3 cookie. The staff was a bit aloof as well.

The place is cute but the narrow hallway setup of it makes it unappealing for me, as I like coffee spots that have lots of light and space. Oh well, tons of other options nearby.
author: Rowena L.

description: I have been to Stanza several times over the past few weeks and it has never failed to deliver good coffee in a friendly environment. The staff has been easy going and always up for chatting. The space is visually appealing with great vintage chairs/tables- perfect for studying and just relaxing with a good book!
author: Frank L.

description:
Spilled drink and asked for napkins, barista asked me what I had and remade drink without me even asking.  

Had a chai which was definitely stellar.
author: RD r.

description:
(See pics) Review #1168. Brought to us by the wine gurus Kris and Mark who are known from Saison and Vinyl. Their own labeled wines (under MJ Lords) are finally available in full range here. You might even have tried a couple of them at Vinyl.

The forever changing grape scene makes the wines more versatile and each time for each year, while you can trace all the consistent varietals, you will also find a couple additional elements that make the wines very unique.

And while it's on Haight Street, finally, it's not divey, but more lounge feel. The bar serves coffee and pastries too but the heart of it is to walk further to the back to chill out at this wine bar, a great way to relax your feet from cruising down Golden Gate Park, or up and down from shopping, or going from or to a movie, or even simply to enjoy some conversations and leave the busy notes outside for a bit.

They even made the label Love Haight just for this very location, but I particularly LOVE the handwritten label ones!
author: T L.

description: Lovely little coffee shop with amazing cappuccinos and chai lattes (not too sweet like so many others). Nice seating area with good folky music and interesting artworks. Smells amazing in here!
author: Rhea N.

description:
Nice atmosphere.
Limited seating.
Fairly good coffee.
Modern Hipster vibe.
No GF or vegan treats.
No Almond milk.
author: Krish K.

description:
Having lived in Seattle for 5 years, this place felt like I was walking into a shop on Broadway in Capitol Hill. The coffee was a bit pricey for me, and the baked goods seemed cute but tasted a bit off. I enjoyed the overall experience, the coffee was on the medium roast side, and I am a fan of dark roast. 

For a more in depth look check out my food blog link: http://msdinnertable.com/2013/01/07/stanza-on-haight-street/

I would recommend this place to a friend, and I would see myself going there every once and a while for a meet up or to read a magazine.
author: Anthony C.

description: The latte was just barely ok. The barista was pleasant. The loud music? Not at all conducive to sitting and enjoying the barely ok latte. Don't waste your time or money here. Plenty of excellent brews in the Haight. This isn't one of them.
author: Junee F.

description: Coffee and shop are ok. Just DO NOT ASK FOR YOUR "warm" coffee to be made hotter. They have to make a new cup AND THEY DON'T LIKE TO DO THAT.  Thankfully there are other. places on Haight.
author: Alston L.

description:
My first time here. Good location and the house coffee war okay but a bit weak for my taste.

Sadly, the music was so loud I could never come here with anyone I'd care ta have a conversation with.
author: Stephen S.

description:
Good espresso. Nice ambiance. But I didn't order a dose of attitude with my cappuccino. And apparently (according to some other reviews), I'm not the only one who's been dished some snarky rudeness from the aloof, we're-too-cool-for-you hipsters behind the bar.

Despite it being a chilly, Karl-filled day, the door was wide-open. Which is fine. I live in San Francisco; I dress in layers. But when the cigarette smoke wafting into the cafe was so strong that my throat stung and my eyes watered (seriously, I might as well have been smoking the cigarette myself), I thought that *perhaps*, rather than be confrontational and say anything to the two guys smoking less than a foot from the entrance, I could just quietly close the door. Apparently not. The guy behind the counter (the same one that other reviewers have noted smokes less than a foot from the door himself) said, "Actually, we need the door open. It gets humid in here." And that would be fine. But he didn't have to say it with a rude and condescending tone, and, furthermore, it's not as if they actually roast their own beans at Stanza. THAT gets humid. I've been in plenty of roasteries, many of which in places that experience sub-freezing temperatures for 6 months of the year. They had their doors shut. And yes, it gets a little humid--with the awesome thick, and sweet smell of coffee ... I digress. Point is, I've been in Stanza before when the front door was closed, and they also have a back door that could be opened instead. But nonetheless, I didn't argue. I reopened the door, and simply said, "Ok. Is it alright then if I ask the people smoking outside to just move downwind?"

He rolled his eyes at me. Overtly. I kid you not. Then, in a tone even ruder and more condescending than before, said, "No. It's Haight Street. It happens. Get used to it. Welcome to The Haight." And he laughed out loud, rolled his eyes some more, and muttered further mockery under his breath to the other barista and to a customer who apparently was more the type he appreciated serving. (Because we've heard from other reviewers that they will ignore customers flat-out in order to "serve those who work on Haight Street first.")

I'm all for neighborhood pride. I'm all for matching expectations to the environment (and don't mind at all when my morning coffee is interrupted by police and paramedics responding to overdose episodes outside Coffee to the People). It's Haight St. I get it. I'm also all for going the extra mile to keep local patrons happy. But, I'm also all for politeness and kindness to everyone, regardless of whether or not they appear to be worthy of your oh-so-hip and pretentiously-unpretentious Haight Street groopies. 

You wanna keep your door open so your buddies can smoke outside and your customers can relish in the fumes of secondhand smoke, because, "It's Haight Street. Get used to it."? That's fine. I might not come back, but I wouldn't be writing this review. I'm writing this review because you were extremely rude about it. No one likes to be laughed at.

Thanks for "Welcoming me to The Haight." 

And, for the record, (not that it should matter), I actually live here. On Ashbury St. And I definitely won't be coming back. Which is too bad, because you do make good coffee. So, grudgingly, I couldn't give you just one star.
author: Bronwyn V.

description:
This is the best espresso I have ever had.  So smooth and rich.   Words cannot explain the wonder I felt upon trying it...I did a little jump for joy on the inside.

Service was good and the baristas were friendly.   The seating is a bit limited so expect you may not get any space.   

Highly recommend!
author: Courtney R.

description: Great coffee and a nice relaxing morning ambiance is the best cure for a bit of jet lag. Stanza provides both along with a great seat to watch the Haight wake up.
author: Josh S.

description:
At work I'm under immense pressure to become a Coffee Aficionado. An amateur among big-leaguers, I feel a little in over my head--but places like Stanza are helping me learn the importance and significance of a perfectly crafted, delicious cup of high-quality caffeination. 

Every time I come into Stanza, the staff are so absolutely lovely and they really do put maximum TLC into every cup they pour. I wish I could come in every single day, the coffee is so amazing. Stanza has converted me from a person who drank coffee for the productivity benefits and ritualistic nature to a person who drinks coffee because I appreciate the craft, time, and flavor that goes into each cup. 

God, I'm started to sound so San Franciscan.
author: Meredith C.

description: Great ambiance and great coffee. Staff is very friendly and treat regulars very kindly. Only avoid this place if you are a loser/poser.
author: Jakob B.

description: Mixed experience. Coffee was good. Employee ( young man with glasses) smoking cigarette at the backdoor. Barely had his foot out the door. Smoke bellowing in cafe lead to a total turn off. Have you employees that smoke away from the door.
author: Linda L.

description:
Stanza was a very welcome respite for us as we walked SF a few weeks ago. Our phones were deader than dead, and Stanza gave us and our phones all the fuel we needed. Outlets at every seat, even the counter! Bless!

Great coffee (thank you for an outstanding decaf), and ok pastries. Nice decor, but very strange and unwelcoming bathroom situation. You have to walk down two corridors that are super shady (you can get kidnapped out a side door - hey, as a chick you have to watch all exits, you know?) and FILTHY FILTHY bathrooms. Emergency purposes only!

If you don't have to go pee, then definitely hang out at Stanza and get a coffee. Lovely staff, too.
author: Ana R.

description:
You think I'M a coffee nerd? I've got nothing on these guys.

Every one of the staff at Stanza is obsessed with The Art Of The Cup, and know things about coffee that I didn't even know could be known about coffee. My mouth is literally agape when they proselytize about the dry process method, or about the power of their Slayer machine (at the other location), or about their varieties from Yirgacheffe like Idido. They are constantly tasting, touching and perfecting their craft at this modest spot on Haight street. You'd never know by walking by that you're in the presence of true coffee deities, and now that I think about it, I'd almost prefer you walk on by and leave me in peace with my drip, no cream, thank you.

The serve beans from Augie's Roasters in pourover, espresso and cold brewed styles. And when you've over-caffeinated yourself, grab a glass of wine and stay until close. This is the hangout. 

Obligatory Title Pun: Go-stanza!

Menu Readability: Just talk to 'em.

Need to mention: The barista Dustin is really bad at fist-bumps and/or handshakes. 

What this place teaches me about myself: I miss my life in the Upper Haight.
author: Vivek S.

description:
I really like the coffee at Stanza - I left a 5-star review saying as much for the other location in the Mission (see http://www.yelp.com/biz/stanza-coffee-san-francisco?hrid=WP_Ydf4slQQq2w-QVkvJ2g). However, something about this one has always felt a little off to me, so I held off on reviewing it until I settled on an opinion. 

I live a couple of blocks away, so I've come here once or twice a week for about two and a half years. The draw is the aforementioned coffee - nothing else is outstanding. The physical setup is weird, causing an awkward bottleneck and nonexistent flow. On top of that, service ranges from a little to very very slow, and typically involves staff with an apathetic affect. However, until today I was willing to overlook the less stellar aspects of this cafe.

Today I stood in line behind a couple in the process of being served by the guy working the register. He spent awhile chatting with them about coffee, and made recommendations as I waited patiently. Neither he nor the guy at the espresso machine acknowledged me. After a few minutes, some other dude stood behind me in line, and was immediately greeted by both employees, who took his order and started on it while finishing up with the couple. When they left, register guy rang up the new customer. The customer politely (and correctly) indicated that they should help me first. I was so taken aback by the entire situation that I couldn't help asking "yes, why are you helping him before me?" Register guy said, in a super exasperated voice, "I help the people who work on Haight Street first," as if 1) I should magically know where the guy works, and 2) that's a valid reason to totally ignore another customer. I was so put off by his attitude that I walked out without ordering anything.

Anyways. I know this guy is a dick, and I shouldn't judge the entire place based on him. However, his behavior is close enough to the general vibe I've been getting all along that I don't feel comfortable patronizing this business anymore. I don't like being treated like I'm invisible, especially when I'm a regular customer. I'd estimate that I've spent a minimum of $500 here, and you know what? I'm going to spend the next $500 someplace that doesn't leave me in a bad mood. Stanza can stick with the customers it truly values - apparently these are the people who work down the street, and are probably getting free or discounted coffee. Awesome business decision, guys.
author: Janna M.

description: Stopped by for a cappucino. Best cappucino I've had. The staff was friendly and the service was quick. & I'm especially excited because the girl made a heart with my milk!
author: Kristine C.

description:
This gets My full 5 stars because the Coffee is really that good. Their Iced Coffee is enjoyable without any Sugar or Milk, and the Chocolate Chip n Sea Salt Cookie is good (heavily salted) and the Blueberry White Chocolate Muffin was amazing actually. 

Hipster customer service attitude but friendly, awesome location...
author: Michael D.

description:
For all the chai latte fans out there...

I just happened to stumble upon Stanza as I was looking for a place to get a chai latte. When I placed my order with the barista, I was impressed by his knowledge about how to make a drink taste great. What my heart desired was a dirty chai latte but he recommended that since their chai is on the spicy side, the espresso may change the intended flavor. At first, that was a bit disappointing to hear but when I took my first sip, it was love. I've had many chai lattes, but none of them have ever had the kind of creamy, soothing texture that this one did. I wish I got the name of the barista (tan, medium length dark hair) because he definitely knows his stuff.
author: Cyndi L T.

description:
Total hipster coffee joint, for better and worse. The coffee is actually good! But they don't really have their sh*t together with respect to the workflow of serving. There's often a large line up, they start making your coffee before it gets rung up so often there's a bunch of people standing around confused about who is next and what step of the process of being served they or others are in. This makes it sloooow. 

They also basically serve only coffee. A few pastries made elsewhere and that's about it. No brown sugar just white. So, pretty minimal. If you like pour-over coffee that takes 7 minutes to custom brew just for you, and nothing else, and are not in a rush, then this place is lovely especially in off-hours of the day. Otherwise I would hit up another joint.
author: Jessy S.

description: Sorry, I find this joint overrated.  I'll give them that they're nice, and yes, their cold brew machine looks cool but I got one and it was like drinking pure acid.  I thought cold brewing was supposed to get rid of that.  It was also about 60% too expensive.  3.50 for a tiny cup (it had to be 12 oz or less.  For an iced cup...not cool.)  Also, the only natural sweetener they have (or at least did when I stopped by) is white sugar...not cool.
author: David A.

description:
Want a "flat white" in San Francisco?  Look no further!  

Stanza only pours microfoam in both their cappuccino and lattes (makes for a sophisticated mouthfeel that Americans really miss out on!). The cappuccino is the flat white equivalent and the latte was heaven!  They also have incredible cold-press coffee... this place is GREAT!

In six months of asking baristas across America if they could make a flat white, this is only the second place that could deliver.  Go Stanza!!
author: Jema P.

description:
After a lovely day of shopping at all the cute stores on this street my friend and I wanted a place to stop and chill. This place looked awfully cute so we went in. I usually dont like coffee but I thought I'd get a pastry or something.

My friend ordered a poptart and she liked it. I spent a few minutes telling the guy at the counter, not being able to choose between a coffee cake or trying a coffee drink. He suggested a cappucino and I loved it! The cute design was so up my alley I felt bad drinking it! Nice chit chat with the staff and it was lovely sitting at the window on a cloudy afternoon watching the passersby.

Definitely would come here again. I also liked the bathroom setup.
author: Kathy R.

description: Kyoto cold brew & Latte was as good as it gets! Chill music and atmosphere and the patrons are Cali cool. It's a Haight St stop for me.
author: A L.

description:
Can't really get into this place. I'm always open to new coffee spots on haight but Stanza doesn't do it for me. The staff is knowledgeable enough about the origins and flavor notes of the beans but are somewhat unapproachable. The environment seems inviting at first (those barrel table tops are killer) but I found it difficult to settle in. 

There are so many coffee shops in the city that almost exist to be pretentious in their repurposed "homestead-esque" aesthetic. While I always offer new ones the benefit of the doubt, this one didn't seem any different to me.

Really beautiful way to make ice coffee though! For $4 you can get a 12 oz cup of alchemy.
author: Megan D.

description:
Howww did this place slip in on Haight without being rejected by the Haight-Street-Association?  I mean, it's not yet another pipe shop, tattoo parlor, or, or , yes, a second hand 'fashion' store?  Whaaaaaat!

Got in here, ordered an espresso and my friend got a decaf coffee.  Espresso was phenomenal---amazing flavor (I'm an espresso fiend) and served perfect.  The decaf was interesting---super smooth and tasty!  Very nice.  

Sat at the window to do some people-watching, and some guy comes up to the window, picture him pierced/tattooed, and starts licking the window while staring at me, and I'm staring back! The next thing I know I feel something tugging at my arm, and I picture I'm getting another Tattoo! I reset and go back to reality, I'm just at Stanza on Haight---All is good! 

Now, where can I find a smelly expensive vintage T-shirt?
author: Mark K.

description:
It was threatening rain. I was a little chilly. And I really should've been getting back to my hotel ... but the sign said I should come in and get some toast.

Toast? I laughed a little and walked a few steps, then stopped, turned back around and realized that toast -- sourflour toast, in fact -- mightn't be a bad idea ...  

So I stepped in, asked for a latte and glanced at the menu on the count. Toast. With preserves. For about $4. "And I'll take some toast, please." The barista asked if I wanted it for here or to-go, so I craned a little and spied a seat at the bar. "For here," I said.

The latte was lovely and arrived in no time at all. I watched the barista saw into a loaf of bread and pop a couple of slices in a toaster oven. Sipping my latte, I had my doubts still, but they all flew away when the toast -- two slices, each sliced again -- was presented on a little square plate with strawberry preserves and a pat of butter.

And it was exactly what I needed.
author: Thomas S.

description:
I liked this place when it was coco luxe...I used to love the mexican hot chocolate here. But now that it is stanza they only have regular hot chocolate. I tried it once and it was kinda meh.  I don't think I would come back. 

They have other stuff: drip coffee and a couple kinds of wine. The decorations are pretty cool with the barrel tables. Seems like a good place to meet friends or go on a date.
author: Monika L.

description: Iced Mocha with Almond Milk. Best mocha I have ever had. Organic chocolate. Their coffee is super fresh and tasty. I will be ranting about this place to people from now on. I love height street.
author: Roman J.

description:
They have french press coffee, which is $2.50 per cup.  The coffee was good, but they don't give you the press while it brews.  They pour your cup after it brews.  I find that a little strange. 

The place is small, with a few small tables.  Nice relief from the touristy garbage around it.
author: John B.

description:
Great coffee. The people are absolutely a joy. The tables are the perfect height to do work sitting or standing. No annoying Wifi log in process. And the prices are more than reasonable. What more do you want. 

I found this place yesterday. I'll be back today.
author: Chetan M.

description: Meh...better coffee and atmosphere to be had elsewhere. Cashier girl today was too cool for school and didn't know jack about coffee. The barista saved the day. Recommend Flywheel down the street instead.
author: R Y.

description:
mmmm the coffee was amazing! they had an issue with their computer so they were only taking cash! and this was told to us after we had ordered a bunch of stuff, like ham croissants...we gathered whatever cash we had...and we were short a few bucks, the girl apologized and just sold us the stuff for what we had. thanks!

great coffee!
author: Jaime D.

description: Great place - best latés around.  Wonderful staff and patrons.  My number one go-to spot in Upper Haight.
author: Justin P.

description:
Great spot- had a tea as Im trying to take a break from coffee but it was quite nice. 
Came here to work- they have a nice space, free wifi and plenty of spots to hookup a power cord- but the countertops & tables are inexplicably high so its a bit of a back workout to type on a laptop!
author: Daniel C.

description: Nice little neighborhood coffee bar. My girlfriend had the coffee, and we split a cherry almond scone. The coffee tasted great, as did the scone. The place is pretty normal size for a coffee shop, and there is plenty of seating.
author: Zach H.

description: Solid soy latte. Cute bar seating. Hope they turn the outside backspace into a patio. Not the friendliest service but its ok.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I really liked Stanza Coffee! I stopped in pretty close to closing time after hitchhiking down Twin Peaks with a friend (long story...), and there was an empty table for us. It's very well decorated, and the chai tea latte was probably one of the best I've ever had (even outside of San Francisco).
author: Kelly R.

description:
In an age where the deeds of men are often shallow and unrepentant, one shop stands to rectify the human condition. A thoughtful intermingling of sophistication and functionality, Stanza, offers the best espresso and coffee in San Fran full stop! 

The nouveau-modern post-roman pre-mediaval decor brings a touch of clairvoyance to the ancient tradition of pouring water over beans.  Whether you pop in for a quick nosh or plan to set up camp you will not be disappointed!
author: Jesse G.

description: Super cute place to grab coffee or tea with friends. Far classier than most other coffee shops in the area, and both the coffee and tea is awesome. The Egyptian Chamomile is my favorite. Everything is made fresh and delicious!
author: Tara K.

description:
When a previously owned wine bar and chocolate shop can be taken over by new owners who introduce a brand new craft coffee -- in addition to new wine and chocolate -- in the Haight, and they're proving to be successful with it from the start, that's when we might need to realize that great coffee is worth the extra oomph: of time and effort from shop owners, and time and a wee bit more from our wallet. 

These guys have brought in Augie's from Redlands, CA (Southern California, Inland Empire hamlet known for cobblestone streets, a college, Cuco's, Granlund's candy and me yelling, "I love Redlands!" in the streets). And now... they're known for Augie's, who have taken a leap to enter the SF coffee boom. Drip pour overs, pulling shots on a hot rod La Marzocco and a Kyoto cold brew. That Kyoto cold brew has Blue Bottle beat as their roast is a bit more delicate which brings out more cherry tartness on the back of the coffee. 

And it's a Markris wine bar, which is going to keep me around -- it's just like what I really would love to see in my house one day; instead, it's all just three blocks away.
author: Jon A.

description:
An amazing little coffee shop.  I know the owner and the manager. Both very classy, clean and knowledge of coffee and coffee cultures. If my benefits at my job weren't so rad I would live at Stanza. 

The wine is just for tasting..... That part is a little mixed up.

Ah man I should go right now.
author: April F.

description:
The are some sexy people making some really fine coffee drinks for some very discerning consumers. I like to drink my double latte there and enjoy the foam art along with a scone or cookie or something from that diner-esque glass case they have by the "we're too cool and progressive for a register" Ipad with a Square.

Duck in there for relief from the flower power or miserable San Francisco weather
author: Lee S.

description:
in the land of Starbucks and other coffee chains... there stands out a small lil cafe tucked discreetly on Haight St serving the most freakingly amazing latte. I don't know what it is, the bean or the press or the way the barista makes it.. but when he handed me my cup of latte, it looked divine. When i tasted it, I was in heaven :-))

Only thing missing in all this was my usual company to enjoy the latte with!
author: S Krishna S.

description: Great coffee, relaxed. Nice to escape into. Only downer was all the extra wobbly tables that the staff apologised for.
author: Selina B.

description:
Great coffee but be careful, it can be really dirty under the tables so make sure your legs don't touch them or you will get stains on your pant.

But the coffee is great.
author: Stéphane R.

description:
Excellent coffee, but it's the people behind the counter that I like.  They're really nice and unpretentious, and also very attractive.  On top of that, they're playing really pretty Indie music, kind of Belle & Sebastien-esque tunes.  And there are some app developers collaborating and giving each other hugs.  Too cute to not comment.  I like this joint.

One suggestion, the furniture is a little impractical and uncomfortable.  It's a little tricky getting comfy, depending on where you sit.
author: Drew B.

description:
Awesome friendly staff, amazing chai tea latte, and free wifi.

I am yet to experience the rest - but I will be back.
author: Varun V.

description:
Always enjoy coming to this coffee house for a nice late and a nice ambiance. They also have a pretty decent selection of loose leaf tea and delicious pastries. The staff is friendly and interesting and always usually open for conversation. 

Great for people watching!
author: Andrew K.

description:
Guys. 

This place is new and up-and-coming and totally worth it. If you know anything about quality coffee, let me tell you, this place is growing to be compatible with fourbarrel, ritual, and sightglass alike. I heard about it coming and could not wait to try it out!

They serve Augie's coffee from Redlands, CA, which is phenomenal espresso and coffee fresh per order. This place has got it, I'm telling you. Good coffee and good pastries!! I had a cappuccino and a blueberry ginger muffin (AMAZING). 

I have heard their wine is amazing too... I cant wait to come again and try some! This is worth it! Pretty soon everyone will be talking about this place... Dont miss out. be one of the first to spread the word!

We all know in San Francisco we pride ourselves on the ability to distinguish good coffee and supporting local businesses. Add this to your list! SO SO GOOD.
author: Sylvia E.

description:
Like everyone else is saying, best coffee in the Haight. You get quality coffee without any of the 'tude. These baristas are knowledgeable and actually smile.

Free coffee cuppings on the first Thursday of the month. 

tags: Augie Coffee, wifi, wine, chocolate, open until 10, Kyoto style drip coffee, super nice baristas.
author: Amanda N.

description: The epitome of hipster coffee shop. Right on haight, wine barrel tops as table, and a very limited selection of high-quality cafe drinks. That all being said, this is actually one of my top few spots in the neighborhood to come for a chai whether with a friend, just to read, or to actually get some work done.
author: Milan T.

description:
Since trying the amazingly delicious Kyoto and New Orleans style iced coffees at Blue Bottle, I haven't been able to be happy settling for just any iced coffee.  I've been on a quest to find that same quality at other cafes.  Luckily, San Francisco has many coffee shops that do it right...you just have to find them.
 
Today, I found Stanza (thanks to Yelp).  They make Kyoto style iced coffee, which I didn't really know anything about (other than that it's good - sophisticated, I know!) until reading this article: http://tmagazine.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/07/29/ristretto-kyoto-to-stay/.  It takes MUCH longer to brew, and has an unmistakable flavor - once you've had it, you'll compare every other coffee in your life to it.  It doesn't need any cream or sugar added.  So now, there are two types of coffee shops - the ones that make iced coffee this way, who treat coffee brewing and latte making like a craft, and the ones who don't.  Stanza is the first kind.
 
As for the coffee shop itself, it's very cute inside, but there aren't an abundance of seats, and I wouldn't describe it as "comfy."  If  you come during peak time, you may not get a place to sit, which doesn't matter anyway if you're just looking to get coffee to go.  The service was pleasant enough, but not warm. 
 
However, they still deserve 5 stars, because the only thing that REALLY matters - the quality of their product - is excellent.
author: Ashley M.

description: Bitter coffee with wacky top. Hipster staff too cool to smile. Card reader doesn't work. Bathroom stinks like homeless encampment.
author: Eater S.

description:
Awesome, nice selection of chocolates, delicious coffee, great environment. 

Stop here!
author: John W.

description:
Don't underestimate the steadiness of those tables. I spilled half my coffee by slightly touching a table. The dude who works here literally saw it and ignored me. That's cool, dude. I'll just clean it up and leave in shame. 

Anyway, the coffee was alright. At the time of my trip here, they only had bright acidic coffees and that's not really my jam. I probably wouldn't return here because of shame, etc and not because the coffee wasn't good. Although as another Yelper said, the music is pretty loud.
author: k h.

description: yay! Just what the neighborhood needed.  Finally a good cup of coffee in the Haight.   Thank you Chris for starting my day off with a delicious cappuccino and disco before noon.
author: sandy c.

description:
May I have a crush on a cafe?  Is that okay?  Because if it is...

Well, I have a crush on Stanza. (Yes, I did just giggle like a schoolgirl as I typed that).

Not only is the staff friendly, inviting, and easy on the eyes...but the chocolate is divine, and they're always willing to help you make your choice of beverage!  I've gone in for iced coffee (oh man, the Kyoto ice coffee is definitely to die for), wine, and various espresso drinks.  I've also sampled the hot chocolate and the cupcakes (although I'm not that big a sucker for not-Sprinkles-on-Santa-Monica-Drive cupcakes), and I must say I haven't yet been disappointed.

The staff is also awesome, especially since I was having a spazzy moment and trying to figure out how to flip their little ipad-that-functions-as-the-register back to face them, and was failing rather miserably.  They totally took the time to flip it, show me how to flip it, and didn't laugh to hard at my emulate-a-5-year-old-at-Disney-for-the-first-time look of awe.

Also, gotta love the decor; who wouldn't get a kick out of wine-barrel tabletops?
author: Emilynne A.

description: The barristas are talented and very friendly.   They make delicious, carefully crafted coffee and are really nice about it.  I almost feel like I made friends here.  Thanks!  They also let you plug in your laptop here and there are lots of outlets.  Come here for great coffee made with a good attitude too!
author: Brooke W.

description: Good pressed coffee.
author: Virginia M.

description:
I don't have a trained palate to decipher the "hint of berry" or the "note of earth" in wine.  Even with beverages I do drink and enjoy, like coffee and tea, I can only use adjectives like "good" or "bad" to describe their qualities.  But finally, at Stanza, after a few sips of the Kyoto iced coffee, I can say with confidence that I detected something fruity in the nice, rich, strong coffee.  So in summary, the coffee is good.

And the place is super cute too. Dressed like a wine bar, but welcoming enough to host the afternoon coffee drinkers.  With the windows wide open, you can watch the transients walk by, and wonder if you are stuck between some sort of time warp of old Haight grunge and new Haight posh.
author: Candice B.

description:
Pros:
- close to where I'm staying
- pretty clean and tidy
- nice employees
- tasty croissant
- free FAST wifi (11.75 Mbps down / 4.63 up)  

Cons:
- coffee isn't anything impressive 
- very limited food options
- limited seating.  table is wobbly so it's hard to work on.  NOT recommended if you're looking for a comfortable place to work in.  
- They kept the window at the top open so during the rain, so not only was it cold, but rain would get inside onto the table and chairs.  Perhaps they feel the need to keep windows open due to the issue mentioned below?  
- frequented by people who smell like they're homeless, but they have expensive looking possessions so they probably aren't homeless.  Another reviewer said: that this place is filled with "stoned dirty hippies".  This is probably what she's referring to.  Because these people smelled so bad, I couldn't even sit at the counter, so my seat options were even more limited!  

I don't see what all the fuss is about.  With the multitude of coffee shops in the area, I will be trying other ones before venturing back here.
author: cat c.

description: Coffee is decent. If you are looking for a cleaner food establishment in this hipster town, I think it's one of the cleaner coffee/food shops in the "Haight/Ashbury" area. Donuts come from a local bakery and the flavors were unique (apricot ginger :-), lavender chocolate, etc.)  Bathrooms are located in a hallway-way in the back and you have to get someone to buzz you in.
author: Jameri C.

description:
This place used to be my favorite Hot Chocolate spot that used to call bittersweet. I went in yesterday to try out for a new cup of coffee since it's a brand new coffeeshop. I was in the mood for a Mocha this time, and also ordered a chocolate chip cookie for the heck of it. 5 mins later, the friendly barista gave me my mocha, but forgot my cookie, since the line started to get busy, I decided to wait paitiently till I finally gotten her attention to ask for my cookie, at this point I still have yet to take a sip of my mocha.

The barista apologies for making me wait for such a long time, she decided to give my cookie for free! I happily walked out the door, and took a sip of my mocha and a bite of that cookie. 

It was one of the BEST mocha I've ever had, it was warm, sweet, and chocolaty! And the cookie was amazing as well.

You'll never know what you'll get out if you can just ask nicely. :)
author: Chi L.

description:
Joy of joys finally there's a great coffee shop in the Haight! Plus it has a cozy atmosphere, super nice baristas, and pastries from Mission Beach Cafe. 

Does it get any better?

O yeah, there's wine too! 

I've only been in the mornings so this review is just for the coffee which is fantastic. Will definitely be coming in to try the wine tho. Seems like a really chill place to hang out with friends and watch people on their awkward first dates.
author: Mary L.

description:
The baristas work espresso like they're sixth generation masters. Sweet dreams were made of their cookies and vegan donuts. Yes, vegan donuts - not only are they real but these thought-to-be mystical creatures are quite scrumptious. Music: progressive and on point. Atmosphere: cozy but comfortable. 

The place embraces coffee culture and swaggy decor, and it's a great little cave tucked away in the Haight chaos. If you want an afternoon of leisurely web-surfing at the bar, or window-side people watching, this is the place for you. 

Note: they put the fun in function, so if you're trying to cram or get easily distracted like yours truly, this may not be the place to hammer out work.
author: Sam M.

description: Girlfriend was tired of seeing all the bummy people walking down Haight and wanted to go somewhere low key and Stanza seemed like the exact place she desired. Very clean, hipster and drug addict free coffee and wine shop with great customer service. Burista knew her wine very well and recommended me a nice Cab that I enjoyed very much. The girl had a white mocha which I tried as well and it was on point. So much better than Starbucks. And that coffee/wine combo is IMPECCABLE!
author: Patrick O.

description:
The Kyoto iced coffee is the most flavorful and delicious I have ever had. It tastes like chocolate and whiskey and amazingness.

My only complaint: the wine barrel tables have such a high lip that it is almost impossible to do work.
author: P Z.

description:
Just recently visited Stanza and was happy to see that my favorite cookies are back! Thank you, Stanza, for bringing back the best cookies in the WORLD!
Oh, and your coffee is wonderful too.
author: Mary M.

description: Great coffee: good quality, cosy, all you want. Music too loud perhaps.
author: Damien P.

description: High priced coffee in trendy lil Haight but I don't mind. The vegan donuts - I'm guessing they're not made in house - were delicious, as was my latte. Dark theme and intimate interior, I am a fan.
author: Colleen C.

description:
I was only here for a coffee (Love the foam art!) and some little sweet nibblets, but I would love to return and try the wines!

It's an adorable little spot on haight--one that actually seems pretty true to the area and not infested with all the tourists! We sat at a little table where I could see behind the counter and it looked like a person's kitchen--just really cute and home-y. The service was great and the coffee was as well.

Will be returning, especially on a cold day for the coffee!

Most of the pastries are from Mission Beach Cafe and are delish!
author: An-Nhien L.

description:
The good:  The coffee is tasty.

The great:  The staff are all coffee snobs without being judgmental.

The good:  Generally, the music is excellent (and when it is not - I have requested for a change and got it without complaint).

The meh:  The tables are not conducive to laptops.

The great:  The cold brew.  Hands down the best cold brew I have ever had.

The good:  The wifi has been constantly good.

The meh:  They only have sweet treats (not a single savory thing).

The great:  WooHoo!  Finally good coffee in the Haight!
author: Tia B.

description: What a lovely, quiet way to start the day (& thank you for opening at 7am)! Small & cozy, acoustical music, no loud frappacino machines, comfortable chairs, very much a neighborhood feeling.  Even the muted colors in the paintings on the walls contribute to the peacefulness. The barista Nathan was friendly and on top of his game.  Preheating the coffee cups with blazing hot water was a brilliant touch. The coffee was perfect and the raspberry, lavender muffin was still warm from the oven.  The savory chorizo brioche was a treat. There will be many repeat visits!
author: Melissa B.

description: Great coffee thats close and convenient to USF
author: Page F.

description:
A great place for drinking wine with friends!  They feature smaller local wines and the atmosphere is very cozy.
